header.name: chaos/preprocessor/seq/fold_right_aux.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that accumulates the elements of a from the last element to the first element.

macro.abstract: The macro accumulates the elements of its second argument with the operation specified by its first argument.

param.para:
The operation that is to be used to accumulate the elements of seq. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, elem1, data2, state3)
1 The elem pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the arity of each element in seq.

2 If the auxiliary data is parenthetic, the data pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in the auxiliary data. Otherwise, it must be a single parameter.
3 The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the auxiliary data, __VA_ARGS__.

usage.param: The whose elements are to be accumulated.

op(s, elem, data, state)
The whose elements are to be accumulated.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of accumulating the elements of seq, from right to left, with the user-specified operation. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code (where N is the index of the last element in seq):
op(s, seq[0], data, op(s, seq[1], data, ... op(s, seq[N], data, state) ... ))

An invocation of the operation with the current (s), a particular element (elem), the auxiliary data (data, and the current state (state or __VA_ARGS__) expands to a new state used in the accumulation of subsequent elements (or as the final result of the algorithm if no further elements exist). The operation may also expand to a in terms of (s) that expands to a new state. Expansion to a allows the operation to recurse on itself if necessary.
Invocations of the operation are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with ((s)), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

This macro uses . As a result, the efficiency of the algorithm's use of the , described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm and ignoring the complexity of op, is a constant Θ(2). As such, the algorithm is theoretically capable of processing containing an unrestricted number of elements.
